text:
Matt: When I think of space exploration, I
usually think of
Enterprising space explorers from the future or bug-eyed aliens who traveled untold numbers
of light years to scope us out.
And that’s weird.

I’m a science journalist and my brain goes
straight to fiction without even considering

how real scientists are investigating our
own solar system.

That’s changing now, though, because of
a story involving some wild space chemistry

that I learned about from my friend, JoAnna,
who writes for the science magazine Eos.
JoAnna: Hey.
Matt: Oh hi.

JoAnna: So on its surface, this story is about
one of Saturn’s moons, Titan, and its totally
unexpected chemistry.

But at its core, it’s about how the things
scientists are learning about Titan are shaping

the way we think about our own planet and
our own solar system.
JoAnna: Let me set the stage for you.

Almost exactly 20 years ago, humanity embarked
on its first mission to orbit Saturn.

The Cassini-Huygens mission is a collaboration
between the National Aeronautics & Space Administration--
Matt: NASA?
JoAnna: That’s the one.
And the European Space Agency.
Matt: Eesa?
JoAnna:...maybe?
I say E-S-A.

Anywho, Cassini-Huygens entered Saturn’s
orbit in 2004, which is when the mission split
into its two major parts.
Huygens is a small probe that detached from Cassini orbiter and parachuted onto Titan’s
surface in early 2005.

Meanwhile, Cassini kept doing laps around
the Saturn system.

That’s where our chemistry story actually
comes from.

Cassini has a pretty tight relationship with
Titan.
The spacecraft flew through Titan’s atmosphere.

And Titan’s gravity is actually going to
provide the Cassini with the force it needs

to end its mission in just a few days--by
flinging it into Saturn’s atmosphere and
where it will burn up.
I know.
But let’s not focus on that right now.
Instead, think about what we’ve learned from this mission.
It literally discovered new moons of Saturn.
It explored the plumes of the moon Enceladus.

And it revealed some amazing chemistry on
Titan.
Matt: Yeah, so what is so special about Titan?
JoAnna: I’m glad you asked.
I know the perfect person to answer that question.
She’s over at Johns Hopkins University.

Let me introduce you to
Sarah Hörst, planetary scientist and Titan
evangelist.

Sarah: When people are like what is so interesting
about Titan and I always just want to be like, "What
isn't interesting about Titan?"
Let me start there.
Oh wait, there’s nothing.

The most basic thing we know about Titan's
atmosphere is that it has one, which is weird.

It's the only moon in the solar system that
has a substantial atmosphere.

Then the second thing we know is that it's
mostly nitrogen.
The atmosphere is about 98% molecular nitrogen.

It's the only other substantial molecular
nitrogen atmosphere in the solar system besides
ours here on Earth.

Just those two things mean that Titan is one
of the most interesting objects in the solar
system in my opinion.

JoAnna: As life evolved on Earth, it began
putting a whole bunch of oxygen in our atmosphere.
That’s not happening on Titan.

So this moon is like a window into our past
that lets researchers explore what Earth’s
atmosphere may have been like.

And what it was capable of before life took
root.
One of the big questions is “can atmospheric chemistry actually create molecules to kick-start life?"

But that’s not the only thing that makes
Titan so intriguing.

Sarah: Titan's atmospheric chemistry is just
absurdly complex.

So the heaviest molecule that had been detected
in Titan's atmosphere before Cassini got there
was benzene, which is C6H6.
So it has a mass of 78.

I think our idea of complexity was kind of
like, "Oh, there's benzene in Titan's atmosphere.

That's a super complex molecule to find in
an atmosphere.
This is going to be really exciting."

Then Cassini got there and the mass spectrometer
on Cassini--which is the ion and neutral mass
spectrometer--only goes up to a mass of 100, so it only goes a little bit heavier than benzene.

So of course they do the first fly-through
of Titan's atmosphere and there's signal all
the way up to 100.

And so immediately you know you sent the wrong
instrument.

The thing that was lucky for us is that there's
another instrument on Cassini called CAPS--it's

the Cassini Plasma Spectrometer, which was
designed to study the plasma environment in
the Saturn system.
It was meant to be studying small energetic ions, so electrons, protons, oxygen.
When CAPS was on during the Titan fly-bys, they started getting these really weird signals
It turned out what CAPS was detecting were negative ions that have a mass up to 10,000.

So that's like 800 carbon atoms rather than
like the six that we have in benzene.
JoAnna: Now researchers published this CAPS data about 10 years ago, when Sarah was a
graduate student.

She was developing computer models of Titan’s
atmosphere and these results were so unexpected
they changed the course of her career.
But more on that in a second.
Matt: First, let’s talk about the CAPS data.

Even though CAPS was designed to look at the
small particles Sarah mentioned, it doesn’t
actually measure mass.
It measures energy.

When CAPS was flying through Titan’s upper
atmosphere, it was screaming through a sea

of cold ions, charged particles with low thermal
energy.

The ions were basically just chilling there
as Cassini flew through them at 6 kilometers
per second.

So CAPS measured the energy of the cold ions,
and scientists knew their speed relative to
the spacecraft--that 6 kilometers per second.

Some basic physics could then give them the
particles’ mass.

Here’s Hunter Waite, the principal investigator
on Cassini’s mass spec and CAPS instruments.

Hunter: Since you can measure the energy,
then you get the mass from just the one half
mv squared, the kinetic energy.

So it's kind of a poor man's mass spectrometer,
but it worked pretty darn well.

Matt: Again, it’s not like scientists didn’t
expect to see stuff in Titan’s atmosphere,

but they weren’t expecting the stuff to
be so big, or that they would find it where
Hunter:  This was surprising in that the particles were so massive.

Everybody realized that there was aerosol
surrounding Titan, but the last thing any

of us thought was that they were all being
created 1,000 km above the surface.
Matt: So now the obvious question is what exactly are these aerosols made of?
JoAnna: We don’t know.
Matt: What?
JoAnna: Yeah.
Remember, the ions are too big for Cassini’s mass spec and CAPS wasn’t made to ID monster molecules.

This sort of complication is basically par
for the course for scientists studying Titan.

Sarah: If Titan would ever just once
give up one of its secrets easily instead

of making us work so hard, it wouldn't be
Titan, of course.

JoAnna: Which brings us back to Sarah’s
work.

Remember how I said the CAPS data changed
the course of her research?

She went from using computers to model Titan’s
atmosphere to approximating the moon in experiments.

Her team built a chamber where it can create
conditions that are Titan-like.

So it can use gases, temperatures, and pressures
that would be present on Titan.

Once they have those variables set in the
chamber, they supply energy with UV light

or plasma discharge to see what chemistry
is possible in that environment.

But remember, they can change the conditions,
so the experiments aren’t limited to Titan--they

test environments inspired by Pluto, or Venus,
or extrasolar planets.

Basically, they’ve got a system on Earth
that can explore the atmospheric chemistry
that’s possible out there.
Sarah: Now that we have this chamber in our lab, we can make any atmosphere we want.

And so we're just kind of running around all
over the solar system and the universe at

this point trying to figure out what's happening
in all of these different atmospheres.
JoAnna: Of course, there are limitations.

For instance, they run experiments for three
days, not the eons the universe has had to
evolve its chemical complexities.

Sarah: We're not making the perfect conditions
in the lab, we're doing the best that we can.

I could save NASA a lot of money if I could
just make Titan in my lab.
But unfortunately that's not actually possible.

JoAnna: These lab experiments, along with
computer simulations and telescope observations,

are giving us a better understanding of what’s
happening out there and how.

Still, there are some questions you can answer
only by being there, so some of these chemical
mysteries will remain until we go back.
Sarah: Telescopes are amazing.

We do amazing work from the ground and space-based
observatories.

And we do all this modeling and experiments,
but there are certain measurements where you

just have to physically go there because it’s
the only way to do it.
Matt: So when might we see another mission back to Titan?
JoAnna: Well, there are totally proposals to go back.

Researchers are talking about sending a quadcopter
or a submarine to Titan.

But it’ll be a long time before a mission
actually makes it there.
Matt: Brutal.

JoAnna: I know. It’s a bummer we’re not
going back to Titan anytime soon, but we’ve literally

been talking about one set of data from one
instrument on one mission to one planet in
our solar system.

There are loads of other space probes out
there and more are planned.

For instance, NASA’s planning to send a
mission to Jupiter’s moon, Europa, sometime
in the 2020s.

And ESA’s JUpiter ICy moons Explorer, or
JUICE, is slated to launch in 2022.
Matt: So we’ve got a lot to look forward to.
JoAnna: Totally.

That said, it is a downer that Cassini is
ending.

Matt: Yeah, you wrote about that for Eos,
right?
JoAnna: I sure did.
Matt: Awesome.

We’ve got a link to that and more in the
description, along with much more.

Which upcoming missions are you most JUICEd
up about?
Let us know in the comments.

JoAnna: You know, I think each mission will
be crater and crater than the last.
Matt: Was that a moon pun?
JoAnna: No.
It was a late heavy bombardment pun.
Duh.
Matt: Thanks for watching.
